page.55009:
This is a Section 'place holder'. When the page is loaded, the section (previously defined under 'Sections') is set into the page. The section is then given an alias, so the widget fields within the section can be set using a SectionData object such as SectionData[sectionalias']['widget name', 'field name'].

Your submit_data function can set a key into the SectionData('sectionalias').show attribute with a value of True or False. This can be used to dynamically include the section, or not, at run time. As default the value is True.

Similary SectionData('sectionalias').hide will hide the section, and SectionData('sectionalias').section_class will set a CSS class into the top section element. These values are JSON settable.

You can also set SectionData('sectionalias').multiplier with an integer value of 0 or more. This can be used to dynamically include the section multiple times. If the multiplier is greater than zero, each aliasname will have an underscore and index number appended. So setting widget fields in the first section will need SectionData('sectionalias_0')['widget name', 'field name'].
page.55509:
If you have previously created one or more sections, this feature allows you to insert a section.

You will need to choose a section name alias, which must be unique within the page. Widget fields within the section can be referred to using SectionData('sectionalias')['widget name', 'field name'].

Your submit_data function can set the attribute SectionData('sectionalias').show with a value of True or False. This can be used to dynamically include the section, or not, at run time. As default the value is True.

Similary SectionData('sectionalias').hide will hide the section, and SectionData('sectionalias').section_class will set a CSS class into the top section element.
page.56009:
A validator is assigned to the field which will send data to the server. This page has the following items:

Error Message : If given is the error message to be displayed on the returned page if the validator fails.

If an Error message reference is given rather than an Error Message, then the text from the TextBlock with this reference will be shown as the error message.

If neither Error Message nor Error message reference are given, then the default error message of the widget displaying the error will be shown.

The section alias and name of the widget to show the error message should be given. If the widget to display the error is not in a section, leave the section alias blank. If no widget name is set the pages default error widget will show the message.

Allowed values: Validators can have a set of strings which will be allowed past the test, if not required, do not add any.

Many validators have further parameters, which depending on the validator, will be shown here, and their values changed by the edit link.
page.56109: Many validators have parameters with values. Such a value should be set here.
page.56309: Validators are test functions that will be applied against received data. Several validators are available, grouped into modules, pick a module to view validators available within it.
page.56319: Lists the validators available in this module, choose one to add it to the widget field.
page.70101:
This page describes the functions you should provide, with their arguments and return values.

The functions you need to supply are:

start_call

submit_data

end_call

These are passed to the WSGIApplication object which uses them as a call progresses.

Initially 'start_call' is called when the call is first received, then optionally one or more calls to 'submit_data' depending on how the call is handled.

Finally 'end_call', after which data is sent to the client.  In typical operation these functions populate instances of PageData and SectionData objects with widget field data, and then these are used to update skicall with skicall.update(pagedata). This then fills in field values of the widgets in a 'TemplatePage'.

Your python code should import these exceptions:

from skipole import FailPage, GoTo, ValidateError, ServerError

These can be used by your functions to generate error conditions, or in the case of GoTo, to force a jump to another page.
page.85001:
Widgets have fields of CSS classes and styles which set the look of the widget, and these fields have default values, which are saved in the defaults.json file within the project data directory. You can download this file here - perhaps to be used in other projects, and you can also upload an existing file you may already have. The actual CSS classes themselves are defined in your project CSS pages, therefore to use the look of a project in a new project you will also need the appropriate CSS files. 

Widget default CSS classes:
This option sets fields to the default values on all widgets in template pages. Default values are only applied if a default for the widget and field has been set, and only in page widgets - not in sections.

Project <html> background color:
In general, the background colour of pages are set in each page 'body' element, however on a slowly loading site, before the body is loaded, it can happen that a brief white page is shown.
One solution is to set a background colour in the very first 'html' element of the page. Each template page of your project has the option to set this attribute, and for all such pages, you can set the background colour here. This allows you to change this setting across the entire project without editing each page.

Set CSS class in <body> tags:
The CSS class of the body tag can be set for all template pages in the project. This allows a drastic CSS change throughout the project if required.

Default CSS links:
When new pages are created, default CSS links can automatically be inserted into the page head section. Set the labels of the default links you wish to insert here. This saves you the trouble of editing the page heads manually every time you create a new page. The list order matches the order in which they will be added.

Default javascript links:
Similarly, when new pages are created, default javascript links can automatically be inserted into the page head section. Set the labels of the default links you wish to insert here. This list should always include 'jquery_core' and 'skipole_js' which are needed for correct operation of the framework widgets.

System special javascript files:
You may prefer javascript files to be delivered to client browsers via a CDN server, rather than your own web server.  The skis project holds all the javascript files, and as default the javascript page labels point to these pages in the skis project. However you have the option here of pointing the labels at a CDN service.
responders.about_submit_list: Submit List: An optional set of strings which you may use, they will appear in the skicall.submit_list attribute. If the 'use_submit_list' decorator is used, the submit list can be used to navigate to a function if the list defines 'package name', 'module name' and 'function name'.
responders.checkers.Accept: This responder 'Accepts' received raw data and calls the submit_data function. The received data is set in the skicall.submit_dict attribute beneath a key 'received_data'. This is required when received data is not in widgfield format and without ident information.
responders.checkers.Accept.call_data:
The skicall.call_data attribute is a dictionary, which can be set with any information you require during the course of a call. It's main use being to provide a method of passing data between your start_call, submit_data and end_call functions.

Typically you might include username or authorization status flags in this dictionary, and pass this from your 'start_call' function through to your submit_data function. This status being used to determine what data to return to the client.

This Accept responder does not set any new information into call_data, you are free to add or alter its contents as you wish.
responders.checkers.Accept.final_paragra:
This responder is intended to allow an incoming call, which does not include page idents and widgfields, to submit data. The data will be in a raw dictionary with field names as keys, and values as either strings or lists of strings.

After calling your submit_data function, the target page will be called next, which could be another responder.

If it is not a responder, typically a template page, then your end_call function will be called and the target page widget fields will be filled in from the skicall object.

If your submit_data function raises a FailPage exception, then the fail page will be called instead, or if your submit_data raises a GoTo exception, a jump will be made to the page ident specified by the GoTo.
responders.checkers.Accept.submit_data:
You should define the function:

submit_data(skicall)

This function will be called by the Accept responder with the skicall object as the argument. Typically you would write the function to populate PageData and SectionData objects with widgfields as keys, and values to insert into the fields. These objects are then used to update skicall using skicall.update(pagedata).

This Accept responder requires your function to return 'None'.

On returning from this function the call will be passed to the responder's target page, which could typically be a template page (in which case your end_call function will be called next) or it could be another responder. If required a GoTo exception could be raised to jump elsewhere, or a FailPage exception could be raised to jump to the responders failure page with an error message.
responders.checkers.Accept.submit_dict:
When your function submit_data is called, it will have argument skicall which is an object with attributes pertaining to this call.

The Accept responder sets the skicall.submit_dict attribute as a dictionary with keys:

'number', the number portion of the  ident (project, number) of this responder.
'target_ident', the target page ident.
'fail_ident', the fail page ident.
'project_brief' with the project brief description.
'responder_brief' with the responder brief description.
'error_dict' which is normally an empty dictionary but will contain widgfields and values which have failed validation tests if this is the 'fail' responder called after a validation failure.
'received_data' contains raw data received from the client.
responders.checkers.Accept.target_ident: The target page is the next page this call will be passed on to, typically a template page which will be returned to the calling web browser.
responders.checkers.AllowStore: Takes received data from a submitted form, and stores data submitted by the widgets specified here in the dictionary 'skicall.call_data' with keys equal to the widget tuples submitting the data, the tuples being either (sectionalias,widget,field) or just (widget,field). Any other widget data received causes the project Validation error page to be shown. Missing fields are set in skicall.call_data with empty values, without validation.
responders.checkers.AllowStore.allowed_c: The caller is either the submitting template page (if this is the first responder) or the previous responder passing the call to this page. On failure calls the validation error page.
allowed_callers : An optional list of page idents which can call this responder. If the list is empty then any page ident can call the responder.
responders.checkers.AllowStore.alternate: If this Responder is called directly (perhaps from an external site link) and there is no submitted data, then rather than display an error, the call is diverted to this page - typically the home site of your project.
responders.checkers.AllowStore.call_data:
The skicall.call_data attribute is a dictionary, which can be set with any information you require during the course of a call. It's main use being to provide a method of passing data between your start_call, submit_data and end_call functions.

This AllowStore responder sets the specified widgets as keys into skicall.call_data, each key being a tuple of (widgetname, fieldname), or if the widget is in a section - (sectionalias, widgetname, fieldname). The dictionary values are those received from a form submitted by a client - where the submitting form has the specified widgets.

Any widgets specified here, but which have no data received, are set into call_data with empty string values.
responders.checkers.AllowStore.fields:
This responder takes a set of widgfields. You should input a widgfield as widget name and field name separated by a comma. Or if the widget is in a section - the widgfield is specified as three elements separated by commas - sectionalias, widgetname, fieldname.

When form data is received, the widgfield and its input data value are received by this responder, any widgfield present which does not appear in this list will be considered unwanted data, and will cause the project validate error page to be called. If no widgfields are given here, the caller must not submit any form data.
responders.checkers.AllowStore.final_par: Unless an error has occurred, and your submit_data function has not redirected the call, this responder will now pass the data to the target page, which could be another responder, or a page to be returned, such as a JSON or template page.
responders.checkers.AllowStore.submit_da:
You should define the function:

submit_data(skicall)

If the "Call submit_data" feature is enabled, this function will be called by the AllowStore responder with the skicall object as the argument. Typically you would write the function to populate PageData and SectionData objects with widgfields as keys, and values to insert into the fields. These objects are then used to update skicall using skicall.update(pagedata).

This AllowStore responder requires your function to return 'None'.

On returning from this function the call will be passed to the responder's target page, which could typically be a template page (in which case your end_call function will be called next) or it could be another responder. If required a GoTo exception could be raised to jump elsewhere, or a FailPage exception could be raised to jump to the responders failure page with an error message.
responders.checkers.AllowStore.submit_di:
When your function submit_data is called, it will have argument skicall which is an object with attributes pertaining to this call.

The AllowStore responder sets the skicall.submit_dict attribute as a dictionary with keys:

'number', the number portion of the  ident (project, number) of this responder.
'target_ident', the target page ident.
'alternate_ident', the alternate page ident.
If the calling page submits no ident, and the alternate_ident has been set - this responder sends the call there.  If it has not, then it calls the project validate error page.
'fail_ident', the fail page ident.
'project_brief' with the project brief description.
'responder_brief' with the responder brief description.
'error_dict' which is normally an empty dictionary but will contain widgfields and values which have failed validation tests if this is the 'fail' responder called after a validation failure.
responders.checkers.AllowStore.submit_op: If the submit option is enabled, then this responder will call your submit_data function.
responders.checkers.AllowStore.target_id: Unless any error occurs, the target page is the next page this call will normally be passed on to, typically a template page which will be returned to the calling web browser.
responders.checkers.AllowStore.validate_: If the validate option below is enabled, when the form data consisting of widgfields and their contents are received, these contents will be run through validation tests. This requires that the widgfields in the calling page have validators applied to them, which is done by editing the widget fields when designing the calling page. If the validation fails, the data will not be transferred to call_data and the 'validate fail' page specified here will be called.
responders.checkers.AllowStoreKeyed: Takes received data from a submitted form, and stores widgfields specified here in the dictionary 'skicall.call_data' with keys set here. Any other widgfield received causes the project Validation error page to be shown. Missing fields are set in skicall.call_data with empty values without validation.
responders.checkers.AllowStoreKeyed.allo: The caller is either the submitting template page (if this is the first responder) or the previous responder passing the call to this page. On failure calls the validation error page.
allowed callers : An optional list of page idents which can call this responder. If the list is empty then any page ident can call the responder.
responders.checkers.AllowStoreKeyed.alte: If this Responder is called directly (perhaps from an external site link) and there is no submitted data, then rather than display an error, the call is diverted to this page - typically the home site of your project.
responders.checkers.AllowStoreKeyed.call:
The skicall.call_data attribute is a dictionary, which can be set with any information you require during the course of a call. It's main use being to provide a method of passing data between your start_call, submit_data and end_call functions.

This AllowStoreKeyed responder sets the 'key' strings associated with widgfields which you have specified here as keys into skicall.call_data. The dictionary values are those received from a form submitted by a client - where the submitting form has the specified widgfields.

Any widgfields specified here, but which have no data received, have the keys specified set into skicall.call_data with empty string values.

This allows you to have received data set into skicall.call_data, but with keys of your choosing.
responders.checkers.AllowStoreKeyed.fiel:
The submitted contents of widgfields specified here will be stored in the skicall.call_data dictionary under the corresponding keys set here.

The widgfields are strings of widgetname, fieldname - or if the widget is in a section, sectionaliasname,widgetname,fieldname.

The keys are any string you prefer, empty values are not allowed:
responders.checkers.AllowStoreKeyed.fina: This responder is typically used to provide a key in call_data independent of the widget sending the data, and may be useful in a situation where different pages may submit the same data parameter which is handled by a common submit_data function.
responders.checkers.AllowStoreKeyed.subm:
You should define the function:

submit_data(skicall)

If the "Call submit_data" feature is enabled, this function will be called by the AllowStoreKeyed responder with the skicall object as the argument. Typically you would write the function to read the submitted values from the skicall.call_data dictionary, and then populate PageData and SectionData objects with widgfields as keys, and values to insert into the fields. These objects are then used to update skicall using skicall.update(pagedata).

This AllowStoreKeyed responder requires your function to return 'None'.

On returning from this function the call will be passed to the responder's target page, which could typically be a template page (in which case your end_call function will be called next) or it could be another responder. If required a GoTo exception could be raised to jump elsewhere, or a FailPage exception could be raised to jump to the responders failure page with an error message.

When your function submit_data is called, it will have argument skicall which is an object with attributes pertaining to this call.

The AllowStoreKeyed responder sets the skicall.submit_dict attribute as a dictionary with keys:

'number', the number portion of the  ident (project, number) of this responder.
'target_ident', the target page ident.
'alternate_ident', the alternate page ident.
If the calling page submits no ident, and the alternate_ident has been set - this responder sends the call there.  If it has not, then it calls the project validate error page.
'fail_ident', the fail page ident.
'project_brief' with the project brief description.
'responder_brief' with the responder brief description.
'error_dict' which is normally an empty dictionary but will contain widgfields and values which have failed validation tests if this is the 'fail' responder called after a validation failure.
If the submit option is enabled, then this responder will call your submit_data function.
responders.checkers.AllowStoreKeyed.targ: Unless any error occurs, the target page is the next page this call will normally be passed on to, typically a template page which will be returned to the calling web browser.
responders.checkers.AllowStoreKeyed.vali: If the validate option below is enabled, when the form data consisting of widgfields and their contents are received, these contents will be run through validation tests. This requires that the widgfields in the calling page have validators applied to them, which is done by editing the widget fields when designing the calling page. If the validation fails, the data will not be transferred to call_data and the 'validate fail' page specified here will be called.
responders.checkers.AllowedAccept: Places received data into the skicall.submit_dict attribute under key 'received_data', the caller page must provide its ident otherwise alternate page is called. Received data keys are widgfield tuples. Calls the submit_data function.
responders.checkers.AllowedAccept.allowe: The caller is either the submitting template page (if this is the first responder) or the previous responder passing the call to this page. On failure calls the validation error page.
allowed callers : An optional list of page idents which can call this responder. If the list is empty then any page ident can call the responder.
responders.checkers.AllowedAccept.altern: If this Responder is called directly (perhaps from an external site link) and there is no submitted data, then rather than display an error, the call is diverted to this page - typically the home site of your project.
responders.checkers.AllowedAccept.call_d:
The skicall.call_data attribute is a dictionary, which can be set with any information you require during the course of a call. It's main use being to provide a method of passing data between your start_call, submit_data and end_call functions.

Typically you might include username or authorization status flags in this dictionary, and pass this from your 'start_call' function through to your submit_data function. This status being used to determine what data to return to the client.

This Accept responder does not set any new information into call_data, you are free to add or alter its contents as you wish.
responders.checkers.AllowedAccept.final_:
Any widgfields from any allowed page can be accepted. The caller page must provide its ident, and the received field keys are widgfield tuples.

After calling your submit_data function, the target page will be called next, which could be another responder.

If it is not a responder, typically a template page, then your end_call function will be called and the target page widget fields will be filled in from the skicall object.

If your submit_data function raises a FailPage exception, then the fail page will be called instead, or if your submit_data raises a GoTo exception, a jump will be made to the page specified by the GoTo.
responders.checkers.AllowedAccept.submit:
You should define the function:

submit_data(skicall)

This function will be called by the AllowedAccept responder with the skicall object as the argument. Typically you would write the function to populate PageData and SectionData objects with widgfields as keys, and values to insert into the fields. These objects are then used to update skicall using skicall.update(pagedata).

This AllowedAccept responder requires your function to return 'None'.

On returning from this function the call will be passed to the responder's target page, which could typically be a template page (in which case your end_call function will be called next) or it could be another responder. If required a GoTo exception could be raised to jump elsewhere, or a FailPage exception could be raised to jump to the responders failure page with an error message.

When your function submit_data is called, it will have argument skicall which is an object with attributes pertaining to this call.

The AllowedAccept responder sets the skicall.submit_dict attribute as a dictionary with keys:

'number', the number portion of the  ident (project, number) of this responder.
'target_ident', the target page ident.
'alternate_ident', the alternate page ident.

'responder_brief' with the responder brief description.

responders.checkers.AllowedAccept.target: Unless any error occurs, the target page is the next page this call will normally be passed on to, typically a template page which will be returned to the calling web browser.
responders.checkers.AllowedFields: Takes a list of widgfields. Any which do not appear in the received form data will be assumed received with an empty value, and will pass through validation tests if set. If any widgfield is received which is NOT in this list, it will be considered unwanted data, and will cause the project validate error page to be called. If the submit data option is True, then received data is placed in the skicall.submit_dict attribute under key 'received_data', which itself contains a dictionary of widgfield tuples against values.
responders.checkers.AllowedFields.allowe: The caller is either the submitting template page (if this is the first responder) or the previous responder passing the call to this page. On failure calls the validation error page.
allowed callers : An optional list of page idents which can call this responder. If the list is empty then any page ident can call the responder.

The skicall.call_data attribute is a dictionary, which can be set with any information you require during the course of a call. It's main use being to provide a method of passing data between your start_call, submit_data and end_call functions.

Typically you might include username or authorization status flags in this dictionary, and pass this from your 'start_call' function through to your submit_data function. This status being used to determine what data to return to the client.

This AllowedFields responder does not set any new information into call_data, you are free to add or alter its contents as you wish.
responders.checkers.AllowedFields.fields:
This responder takes a set of widgfields. You should input a widgfield as widget name and field name separated by a comma. Or if the widget is in a section - the widgfield is specified as three elements separated by commas - section name, widget name, field name.

When form data is received, the widgfield and its input data value are received by this responder, any widgfield present which does not appear in this list will be considered unwanted data, and will cause the project validate error page to be called. If no widgfields are given here, the caller must not submit any form data.

If any of the widgfields set here are not present in the received form data, they will be added, with empty string values.
responders.checkers.AllowedFields.final_: Unless an error has occurred, and your submit_data function has not redirected the call, this responder will now pass the data to the target page, which could be another responder, or a page to be returned, such as a JSON or template page.
responders.checkers.AllowedFields.submit:
You should define the function:

submit_data(skicall)

If the "Call submit_data" feature is enabled, this function will be called by the AllowedFields responder with the skicall object as the argument. Typically you would write the function to populate PageData and SectionData objects with widgfields as keys, and values to insert into the fields. These objects are then used to update skicall using skicall.update(pagedata).

This AllowedFields responder requires your function to return 'None'.

On returning from this function the call will be passed to the responder's target page, which could typically be a template page (in which case your end_call function will be called next) or it could be another responder. If required a GoTo exception could be raised to jump elsewhere, or a FailPage exception could be raised to jump to the responders failure page with an error message.

When your function submit_data is called, it will have argument skicall which is an object with attributes pertaining to this call.

The AllowedFields responder sets the skicall.submit_dict attribute as a dictionary with keys:

'number', the number portion of the  ident (project, number) of this responder.
'target_ident', the target page ident.
'alternate_ident', the alternate page ident.
If the calling page submits no ident, and the alternate_ident has been set - this responder sends the call there.  If it has not, then it calls the project validate error page.
'fail_ident', the fail page ident.
'project_brief' with the project brief description.
'responder_brief' with the responder brief description.
'error_dict' which is normally an empty dictionary but will contain widgfields and values which have failed validation tests if this is the 'fail' responder called after a validation failure.
'received_data' contains a dictionary of widgfield tuples:values of data received from the client.
If the submit option is enabled, then this responder will call your submit_data function.
responders.checkers.AllowedFields.target: target page : The ident of the page which, on success, this responder passes the call onto. Note - the target could be another responder which will continue to process the call.
responders.checkers.AllowedFields.valida: If the validate option below is enabled, when the form data consisting of widgfields and their contents are received, these contents will be run through validation tests. This requires that the widgfields in the calling page have validators applied to them, which is done by editing the widget fields when designing the calling page. If the validation fails the 'validate fail' page specified here will be called.
responders.checkers.PageData: Sets widgfield:values given here to be inserted into skicall.
responders.checkers.PageData.fields:
Set a widgfield as the key, such as widgetname, fieldname and a value. Only string values can be accepted - so this responder cannot set boolean, lists or dictionaries. Use your python functions to set such items.

Add widgfield and value, empty values are allowed:
responders.checkers.PageData.final_parag: Normally skicall is populated via your own code, however this responder may be useful where some simple static values need to be set, perhaps depending on the page called.
responders.checkers.PageData.target_iden: Target Page: The label or ident of the page this call is to be passed to.
responders.checkers.PrettyFormData: Places a pretty print string of received widgfield:value's form data into skicall.submit_dict with key 'form_data' and pretty print of received raw data into skicall.submit_dict with key 'raw_data' and calls the submit_data function.
responders.checkers.PrettyFormData.call_:
The skicall.call_data attribute is a dictionary, which can be set with any information you require during the course of a call. It's main use being to provide a method of passing data between your start_call, submit_data and end_call functions.

Typically you might include username or authorization status flags in this dictionary, and pass this from your 'start_call' function through to your submit_data function. This status being used to determine what data to return to the client.

This PrettyFormData responder does not set any new information into call_data, you are free to add or alter its contents as you wish.
responders.checkers.PrettyFormData.final: This responder is typically used for test and diagnostic purposes, the pretty print strings could be placed into a widget as text to be displayed on a page.
responders.checkers.PrettyFormData.submi:
You should define the function:

submit_data(skicall)

This function will be called by the PrettyFormData responder with the skicall object as the argument. Typically you would write the function to populate PageData and SectionData objects with widgfields as keys, and values to insert into the fields. These objects are then used to update skicall using skicall.update(pagedata).

This PrettyFormData responder requires your function to return 'None'.

On returning from this function the call will be passed to the responder's target page, which could typically be a template page (in which case your end_call function will be called next) or it could be another responder. If required a GoTo exception could be raised to jump elsewhere, or a FailPage exception could be raised to jump to the responders failure page with an error message.

When your function submit_data is called, it will have argument skicall which is an object with attributes pertaining to this call.

The PrettyFormData responder sets the skicall.submit_dict attribute as a dictionary with keys:

'number', the number portion of the  ident (project, number) of this responder.
'target_ident', the target page ident.
'fail_ident', the fail page ident.
'project_brief' with the project brief description.
'responder_brief' with the responder brief description.
'error_dict' which is normally an empty dictionary but will contain widgfields and values which have failed validation tests if this is the 'fail' responder called after a validation failure.
'form_data' with a pretty print string of received widgfield:value's form data.
'raw_data' with a pretty print string of received raw data.
responders.checkers.PrettyFormData.targe: Target Page : The ident or label of the page which this responder passes the call onto. Note - the target could be another responder which will continue to process the call.
responders.checkers.StoreData:
For widgfields set here, takes the received data from a submitted form, and stores it in the dictionary skicall.call_data with keys equal to the widgfield tuples.

Other widgfields and data received, but not specified here, are not set into skicall.call_data. Widgfields set here but not received are set in skicall.call_data with empty values without validation.
responders.checkers.StoreData.call_data:
The skicall.call_data attribute is a dictionary, which can be set with any information you require during the course of a call. It's main use being to provide a method of passing data between your start_call, submit_data and end_call functions.

This StoreData responder sets the specified widgfields as keys into skicall.call_data, each key being a tuple of (widgetname, fieldname), or if the widget is in a section - (sectionalias, widgetname, fieldname). The dictionary values are those received from a form submitted by a client - where the submitting form has the specified widgfields.

Any data received from other widgfields are not inserted into call_data.

Any widgfields specified here, but which have no data received, are set into call_data with empty string values.
responders.checkers.StoreData.fields: This responder takes a set of widgfields. You should input a widgfield as widget name and field name separated by a comma. Or if the widget is in a section - the widgfield is specified as three elements separated by commas - section alias, widget name, field name.
responders.checkers.StoreData.final_para: This responder is useful to store a subset of the data received, without causing an error if further widgfields, not specified here, are also received.
responders.checkers.StoreData.submit_dat:
You should define the function:

submit_data(skicall)

If the "Call submit_data" feature is enabled, this function will be called by the StoreData responder with the skicall object as the argument. Typically you would write the function to read the submitted values from the skicall.call_data dictionary and then populate PageData and SectionData objects with widgfields as keys, and values to insert into the fields. These objects are then used to update skicall using skicall.update(pagedata).

This StoreData responder requires your function to return 'None'.

On returning from this function the call will be passed to the responder's target page, which could typically be a template page (in which case your end_call function will be called next) or it could be another responder. If required a GoTo exception could be raised to jump elsewhere, or a FailPage exception could be raised to jump to the responders failure page with an error message.
responders.checkers.StoreData.submit_dic:

'number', the number portion of the  ident (project, number) of this responder.
'target_ident', the target page ident.
'fail_ident', the fail page ident.
'project_brief' with the project brief description.
'responder_brief' with the responder brief description.
'error_dict' which is normally an empty dictionary but will contain widgfields and values which have failed validation tests if this is the 'fail' responder called after a validation failure.
responders.checkers.StoreData.submit_opt: If the submit option is enabled, then this responder will call your submit_data function.
responders.checkers.StoreData.target_ide: Target Page : The ident or label of the page which, on success, this responder passes the call onto. Note - the target could be another responder which will continue to process the call.
responders.checkers.StoreData.validate_o: If the validate option below is enabled, the widgfields specified here will have their submitted contents validated.  This requires that the widgfields in the calling page have validators applied to them. If the validation fails, the data will not be transferred to call_data and the 'validate fail' page specified here will be called. Validation is not applied to missing fields.
responders.checkers.StoreDataKeyed: For widgfields set here, takes the data from the submitted form, and stores them in the dictionary skicall.call_data.  The dictionary keys used to store these are the keys given here.  Other widgfield received are not set into skicall.call_data. Missing fields are set in skicall.call_data with empty values without validation.
responders.checkers.StoreDataKeyed.call_:
The skicall.call_data attribute is a dictionary, which can be set with any information you require during the course of a call. It's main use being to provide a method of passing data between your start_call, submit_data and end_call functions.

This StoreDataKeyed responder sets the 'key' strings associated with widgfields which you have specified here as keys into skicall.call_data. The dictionary values are those received from a form submitted by a client - where the submitting form has the specified widgfields.

Any data received from other widgfields are not inserted into skicall.call_data.

Any widgfields specified here, but which have no data received, have the keys specified set into skicall.call_data with empty string values.

This allows you to have received data set into skicall.call_data, but with keys of your choosing.
responders.checkers.StoreDataKeyed.field:
Please input one or more widgfields, and associated key values.  When data is submitted to this responder, the submitted contents of these widgfields will be added to the call_data dictionary with these keys.

Add widgfield and key, empty keys are not allowed:
responders.checkers.StoreDataKeyed.final: Please note - this responder does not necessarily move all the submitted data into call_data, it only moves data from the widgfields specified.
responders.checkers.StoreDataKeyed.submi:
You should define the function:

submit_data(skicall)

If the "Call submit_data" feature is enabled, this function will be called by the StoreDataKeyed responder with the skicall object as the argument. Typically you would write the function to read the submitted values from the skicall.call_data dictionary and then populate PageData and SectionData objects with widgfields as keys, and values to insert into the fields. These objects are then used to update skicall using skicall.update(pagedata).

This StoreDataKeyed responder requires your function to return 'None'.

On returning from this function the call will be passed to the responder's target page, which could typically be a template page (in which case your end_call function will be called next) or it could be another responder. If required a GoTo exception could be raised to jump elsewhere, or a FailPage exception could be raised to jump to the responders failure page with an error message.

When your function submit_data is called, it will have argument skicall which is an object with attributes pertaining to this call.

The StoreDataKeyed responder sets the skicall.submit_dict attribute as a dictionary with keys:

'number', the number portion of the  ident (project, number) of this responder.
'target_ident', the target page ident.
'fail_ident', the fail page ident.
'project_brief' with the project brief description.
'responder_brief' with the responder brief description.
'error_dict' which is normally an empty dictionary but will contain widgfields and values which have failed validation tests if this is the 'fail' responder called after a validation failure.
If the submit option is enabled, then this responder will call your submit_data function.
responders.checkers.StoreDataKeyed.targe: Target Page : The ident or label of the page which, on success, this responder passes the call onto. Note - the target could be another responder which will continue to process the call.
responders.checkers.StoreDataKeyed.valid: If the validate option below is enabled, the widgfields specified here will have their submitted contents validated.  This requires that the widgfields in the calling page have validators applied to them. If the validation fails, the data will not be transferred to call_data and the 'validate fail' page specified here will be called. Validation is not applied to missing fields.
responders.fail_page:
The fail page ident is the label or ident of the page to jump to if your submit_data function raises a FailPage exception.

The fail page could be another responder - leading to another template page, however it cannot be to a responder previously called within the course of this call. If this were allowed it could result in infinite loops.

To use the FailPage exception it should be imported into your code using:

from skipole import FailPage

It has arguments:
FailPage(message = '', section='', widget='', failpage=None)

On being raised, this makes the Responder call the fail page with an error message. If the failpage argument is None, the fail page called is the one set when creating the Responder.  You would normally only set a failpage label or ident in the exception if you wanted particular pages to be displayed for specific errors.

The arguments; message together with section alias and widget name indicate where the message is to be displayed on the fail page.

Their default values are empty strings, leave as empty if you do not wish to pass any information. If the section/widget are not given the message will be shown in the fail page default error widget.
responders.navigators.CaseSwitch: Checks a single submitted widgfield content against a list, and if a match occurs, passes the call to an associated page. If there is no match, the page specified by 'alternate_ident' will be called.
responders.navigators.CaseSwitch.alterna: If no match is found, the call goes to the page set here, as either an ident, label or url. However this is not considered an error, and no error message will be raised.
responders.navigators.CaseSwitch.fields: A list of possible values submitted in the widgfield with corresponding target pages to go to. The target pages can be idents, labels or urls
responders.navigators.CaseSwitch.final_p: The outcome of this responder is that the call is passed on to a further page (which could be another responder) depending on the value submitted.
responders.navigators.CaseSwitch.widgfie: The widgfield which is to have its contents checked must be specified, set the widget name and field name separated by a comma. (Or section name, widget name, field name if the widget is part of a section).
responders.navigators.DelCallDataItem: For a single given key in skicall.call_data; if present, that key:value will be deleted.
responders.navigators.DelCallDataItem.fi: Set the key string in skicall.call_data which is to be deleted.
This responder may be required if an item in skicall.call_data is likely to cause problems in a subsequent responder.
responders.navigators.DelCallDataItem.ta: The target page is the ident or label of the page to go to after the key:value has been deleted.
responders.navigators.EmptyCallDataGoto: For a single given key in the skicall.call_data dictionary, if skicall.call_data has that key with an empty value or the key is not present, then passes the call to the target page, otherwise passes the call to the alternate page.
Alternate page: The ident or label of the page to go to if skicall.call_data has that key with an non-empty value.
The entry here is the key of skicall.call_data to check.
Typically used to choose different pages to show depending on a field set in skicall.call_data.
Target Page: The ident or label of the page to go to if skicall.call_data has that key with an empty value or the key is not present.
responders.navigators.EmptyGoto: For the given widgfield, if the received form data has that widgfield with an empty value or the widgfield is not present, then passes the call to the target page, otherwise passes the call to the alternate page.
responders.navigators.EmptyGoto.allowed_: The caller is either the submitting template page (if this is the first responder) or the previous responder passing the call to this page. On failure calls the validation error page.
A list of allowed caller pages can be set here, if any value is given then a call from any other page not listed will produce the project validate error page.
responders.navigators.EmptyGoto.alternat: Given a Widgfield set above, checks its presence and contents. If the received form contains the widgfield with data, then pass the call on to the Alternate Page.
responders.navigators.EmptyGoto.final_pa: If a call to this responder is made without page ident data (such as from a page that submits no data), then the project validation error page will be returned.
responders.navigators.EmptyGoto.target_i: If the Widgfield is not present, or contains empty data then pass the call on to the Target page.
responders.navigators.EmptyGoto.widgfiel: widgfield: A widget name and field name separated by a comma. This framework will accept this as a tuple of 'widgetname, fieldname'. This defines the field submitted by the original calling template page which is to be checked.
responders.navigators.NoOperation: Passes the call on to the target page.
responders.navigators.NoOperation.final_: Can be used to give an alternate URL to a target page, or as a placeholder while a site is under development, to eventually be replaced later by another responder.
responders.navigators.NoOperation.target: Target Page: The ident or label of the page this call will be passed to.
responders.submitters.ColourSubstitute: Calls your submit_data function which should return a dictionary of {keystring : css_colour, ...}. These colours will be inserted into a target css page substituting the colours for the keystrings.
responders.submitters.ColourSubstitute.c:
The skicall.call_data attribute is a dictionary, which can be set with any information you require during the course of a call. It's main use being to provide a method of passing data between your start_call, submit_data and end_call functions.

Typically you might include username or authorization status flags in this dictionary, and pass this from your 'start_call' function through to your submit_data function. This status being used to determine what data to return to the client.

'target_ident', the target page ident.

responders.submitters.ColourSubstitute.t: The target page of this responder should be a CSS page generated by this framework, not a static CSS file page, as the framework is not yet able to parse external CSS pages.
responders.submitters.FieldStoreSubmit: Calls your submit_data function. Takes received form data with a field specified here (regardless of widget name - only uses field name to choose data), and stores the received data in skicall.submit_dict under key 'received', with value being a dictionary with keys being the widgfield tuples of the submitting widgets, and values being the data.
responders.submitters.FieldStoreSubmit.c:
The skicall.call_data attribute is a dictionary, which can be set with any information you require during the course of a call. It's main use being to provide a method of passing data between your start_call, submit_data and end_call functions.

Typically you might include username or authorization status flags in this dictionary, and pass this from your 'start_call' function through to your submit_data function. This status being used to determine what data to return to the client.

This FieldStoreSubmit responder does not set any new information into call_data, you are free to add or alter its contents as you wish.
responders.submitters.FieldStoreSubmit.f:
Set the fieldname to be searched for.

All widgets submitting data with this common field name will have their data stored in skicall.submit_dict under key 'received'.

Please note that data is inserted into a dictionary held within skicall.submit_dict['received'], not call_data.  If no match to the field name given is found, skicall.submit_dict['received'] will be an empty dictionary.
responders.submitters.FieldStoreSubmit.s:
You should define the function:

submit_data(skicall)

This function will be called by the FieldStoreSubmit responder with the skicall object as the argument. Typically you would write the function to populate PageData and SectionData objects with widgfields as keys, and values to insert into the fields. These objects are then used to update skicall using skicall.update(pagedata).

This FieldStoreSubmit responder requires your function to return 'None'.

On returning from this function the call will be passed to the responder's target page, which could typically be a template page (in which case your end_call function will be called next) or it could be another responder. If required a GoTo exception could be raised to jump elsewhere, or a FailPage exception could be raised to jump to the responders failure page with an error message.

When your function submit_data is called, it will have argument skicall which is an object with attributes pertaining to this call.

The FieldStoreSubmit responder sets the skicall.submit_dict attribute as a dictionary with keys:

'number', the number portion of the  ident (project, number) of this responder.
'target_ident', the target page ident.

'field' with the field name set in the responder.
'received' contains a dictionary. The dictionary keys are the widgfield tuples of the received form which have the field name matching the specified field. The dictionary values will be the values received with these widgfields.
responders.submitters.FieldStoreSubmit.t: After submit_data is called, the call is passed on to the target page (unless submit_data raises an exception to divert the call elsewhere).
responders.submitters.GetDictionaryDefau: Web browsers do not send empty fields, therefore a submitted dictionary may have items missing. This responder calls your submit_data function which should return the expected dictionary with default values. Any missing fields in the received form data are then filled in with these defaults.  Any dictionary key received which is not in the default dictionary will cause the project validate error page to be called.
The caller is either the submitting template page (if this is the first responder) or the previous responder passing the call to this page. On failure calls the validation error page.
Allowed Callers : An optional list of page idents which can call this responder. If the list is empty then any page can call the responder.

The skicall.call_data attribute is a dictionary, which can be set with any information you require during the course of a call. It's main use being to provide a method of passing data between your start_call, submit_data and end_call functions.

Typically you might include username or authorization status flags in this dictionary, and pass this from your 'start_call' function through to your submit_data function. This status being used to determine what data to return to the client.

This GetDictionaryDefaults responder does not set any new information into call_data, you are free to add or alter its contents as you wish.
fail_ident: If you raise a FailPage exception in your submit_data function then the fail_ident page will be called.
This Responder is only valid for a widgfield that is used to send a dictionary.

You should define the function:

submit_data(skicall)

This function will be called by the GetDictionaryDefaults responder with the skicall object as the argument.

This GetDictionaryDefaults responder requires your function to return a dictionary containing keys which are expected to match the keys in the dictionary received from the client with the given widgfield.

Any missing key received will be inserted into the received dictionary with the value from the default dictionary returned by submit_data().

Any key received that is not in the default dictionary will cause the Validation Error page to be displayed.

When your function submit_data is called, it will have argument skicall which is an object with attributes pertaining to this call.

The GetDictionaryDefaults responder sets the skicall.submit_dict attribute as a dictionary with keys:

'number', the number portion of the  ident (project, number) of this responder.
'target_ident', the target page ident.
'fail_ident', the fail page ident.
'project_brief' with the project brief description.
'responder_brief' with the responder brief description.
'error_dict' which is normally an empty dictionary but will contain widgfields and values which have failed validation tests if this is the 'fail' responder called after a validation failure.
'widgfield' with the widgfield tuple set in the responder.
Target Page : The ident or label of the page which, on success, this responder passes the call onto. Note - the target could be another responder which will continue to process the call.

widgfield : The widgfield which will contain the dictionary, input as a widget name and field name separated by a comma, or if the widget is contained within a section; as section name, widget name and field name.
responders.submitters.MediaQuery: This responder applies a set of Media Queries against target SubmitCSS or CSS pages, setting their contents within media query blocks, and returns an aggregate CSS page of all the blocks.
responders.submitters.MediaQuery.call_da:
The skicall.call_data attribute is a dictionary, which can be set with any information you require during the course of a call. It's main use being to provide a method of passing data between your start_call, submit_data and end_call functions.

Typically you might include username or authorization status flags in this dictionary, and pass this from your 'start_call' function through to your submit_data function. This status being used to determine what data to return to the client.

This MediaQuery responder does not set any new information into call_data, you are free to add or alter its contents as you wish.
responders.submitters.MediaQuery.fields:
You should submit a number of media query strings, with targets. So a media string may be something like :

@media (max-width: 960px)

and the associated target will be the ident or label of a SubmitCSS responder or CSS page.  Please note: NOT a static CSS file, this framework does not currently extract contentents from such a file.

Given a number of such queries, the CSS file returned will be a single file containing each of the targets, wrapped in the appropriate media query block.
responders.submitters.MediaQuery.final_p: If the submit_data option is chosen, your submit_data should return a dictionary with keys being media query strings (starting with @media..) and values should be page idents or labels of target SubmitCSS responders or CSS pages.
responders.submitters.MediaQuery.submit_:
You should define the function:

submit_data(skicall)

If the 'Call submit_data' option is enabled this function will be called by the MediaQuery responder with the skicall object as the argument.

The submit_data function should return a dictionary with keys being media query strings (starting with @media..) and values should be page idents or labels of target SubmitCSS responders or CSS pages. This dictionary will update any set in this page.

The CSS file generated will be an aggregate file containing each of the targets, wrapped in the appropriate media query block.

The data transmitted is not taken from skicall apart from the following:

The PageData().cssimport attribute - if this contains a string, or a list of strings, they will be set into the returned file as "@import : string;" statements.

The PageData().status attribute will be used if given
The PageData().headers attribute will be used if given.

Otherwise defaults will be used of:

status = '200 OK'
headers = [('content-type', 'text/css'),
           ('cache-control','no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate'),
           ('Pragma', 'no-cache'),
           ('Expires', '0')]

As this responder generates the file to be returned, the end_call function will be called directly after this call to submit_data.

When your function submit_data is called, it will have argument skicall which is an object with attributes pertaining to this call.

The MediaQuery responder sets the skicall.submit_dict attribute as a dictionary with keys:

'number', the number portion of the  ident (project, number) of this responder.
'fail_ident', the fail page ident.
'project_brief' with the project brief description.
'responder_brief' with the responder brief description.
'error_dict' which is normally an empty dictionary but will contain widgfields and values which have failed validation tests if this is the 'fail' responder called after a validation failure.
'media_target' with a dictionary of the media query:targets set in the responder.
If the submit_data option is enabled, this responder will call your submit_data function which can return a dictionary to update the fields above with further media query:target pairs.
responders.submitters.SetCookies: Calls submit_data which should return cookies to be set into the page returned.
responders.submitters.SetCookies.allowed: The caller is either the submitting template page (if this is the first responder) or the previous responder passing the call to this page. On failure calls the validation error page.
A list of allowed caller pages can be set here, if any value is given then a call from any other page not listed will produce the project validate error page.
responders.submitters.SetCookies.call_da:
The skicall.call_data attribute is a dictionary, which can be set with any information you require during the course of a call. It's main use being to provide a method of passing data between your start_call, submit_data and end_call functions.

Typically you might include username or authorization status flags in this dictionary, and pass this from your 'start_call' function through to your submit_data function. This status being used to determine what data to return to the client.

This SetCookies responder does not set any new information into call_data, you are free to add or alter its contents as you wish.
responders.submitters.SetCookies.final_p:
Your submit_data can return a list of lists, of format [[key, value, max-age],...] - these will be converted into a http.cookies.SimpleCookie object for you. The max-age is integer seconds, and cookies will be created with a path equal to the project path and with the httponly and secure flags set.

Alternatively submit_data can return a http.cookies.BaseCookie or http.cookies.SimpleCookie object containing the cookies which will be set in the returned page.

For example:

Import the cookies module from the standard library.

from http import cookies

And then your submit_data would typically create a cookies.SimpleCookie object and populate it with the cookies you require to send to the client browser - read the library documentation for details.

submit_data should then return the SimpleCookie object, and these cookies will be sent, and in subsequent calls will be returned as key:value strings in the 'skicall.received_cookies' dictionary.

This allows you to specify cookies with the name, value, path and expiration times you require.
responders.submitters.SetCookies.submit_:
You should define the function:

submit_data(skicall)

This function will be called by the SetCookies responder with the skicall object as the argument.

This SetCookies responder requires your function to return a cookie which will be sent to the client. The cookie should be an instance of a http.cookies.BaseCookie which is available in the Python standard library. Typically you would create a http.cookies.SimpleCookie() which is derived from BaseCookie. 

For example if your code has:

from http import cookies

you could have a submit_data function which includes:

cki = cookies.SimpleCookie()
cki["ping"] = "pong"

and return cki

On subsequent calls you should find that skicall.received_cookies["ping"] should equal "pong".

When your function submit_data is called, it will have argument skicall which is an object with attributes pertaining to this call.

The SetCookies responder sets the skicall.submit_dict attribute as a dictionary with keys:

'number', the number portion of the  ident (project, number) of this responder.
'target_ident', the target page ident.
'fail_ident', the fail page ident.
'project_brief' with the project brief description.
'responder_brief' with the responder brief description.
'error_dict' which is normally an empty dictionary but will contain widgfields and values which have failed validation tests if this is the 'fail' responder called after a validation failure.
responders.submitters.SetCookies.target_: Target Page : The ident or label of the page which this responder passes the call onto. Note - the target could be another responder which will continue to process the call.
responders.submitters.SubmitCSS: This responder creates a dynamic CSS file. It calls the submit_data function which should return a 'style' - being a dictionary with keys being css selectors and values being a list of two element lists acting as css declaration blocks. This will be returned to the client as a CSS page. The page_type argument of the end_call function will be 'SubmitCSS'.
responders.submitters.SubmitCSS.call_dat:
The skicall.call_data attribute is a dictionary, which can be set with any information you require during the course of a call. It's main use being to provide a method of passing data between your start_call, submit_data and end_call functions.

Typically you might include username or authorization status flags in this dictionary, and pass this from your 'start_call' function through to your submit_data function. This status being used to determine what data to return to the client.

This SubmitCSS responder does not set any new information into call_data, you are free to add or alter its contents as you wish.
responders.submitters.SubmitCSS.final_pa: The style returned by submit_data should be an ordered dictionary with keys being css selectors and values being a list of two element lists acting as css declaration blocks.
responders.submitters.SubmitCSS.submit_d:
You should define the function:

submit_data(skicall)

This function will be called by the SubmitCSS responder with the skicall object as the argument.

This SubmitCSS responder requires your function to return a dictionary containing data which will be returned to the calling client as a CSS file.

The returned dictionary should be an ordered dictionary with keys being css selectors and values being a list of two element lists acting as css declaration blocks.

The data transmitted is not taken from skicall apart from the following:

PageData().cssimport attribute - if this contains a string, or a list of strings, they will be set into the returned file as "@import : string;" statements.

PageData().status attribute will be used if given
PageData().headers attribute will be used if given.

Otherwise defaults will be used of:

status = '200 OK'
headers = [('content-type', 'text/css'),
           ('cache-control','no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate'),
           ('Pragma', 'no-cache'),
           ('Expires', '0')]

As this responder generates the file to be returned, no target page is requested, and the end_call function will be called directly after this call to submit_data.

When your function submit_data is called, it will have argument skicall which is an object with attributes pertaining to this call.

The SubmitCSS responder sets the skicall.submit_dict attribute as a dictionary with keys:

'number', the number portion of the  ident (project, number) of this responder.
'fail_ident', the fail page ident.
'project_brief' with the project brief description.
'responder_brief' with the responder brief description.
'error_dict' which is normally an empty dictionary but will contain widgfields and values which have failed validation tests if this is the 'fail' responder called after a validation failure.
responders.submitters.SubmitData:
This responder calls your submit_data function with a skicall object as argument. Typically you would write the function to populate PageData and SectionData objects with widgfields as keys, and values to insert into the fields. These objects are then used to update skicall using skicall.update(pagedata).

The function should return None.
responders.submitters.SubmitData.allowed: A list of allowed caller pages can be set here, if any value is given then a call from any other page not listed will produce the project validate error page.
allowed callers : An optional list of page idents which can call this responder. If the list is empty then any page ident can call the responder.
responders.submitters.SubmitData.call_da:
The skicall.call_data attribute is a dictionary, which can be set with any information you require during the course of a call. It's main use being to provide a method of passing data between your start_call, submit_data and end_call functions.

Typically you might include username or authorization status flags in this dictionary, and pass this from your 'start_call' function through to your submit_data function. This status being used to determine what data to return to the client.

This SubmitData responder does not set any new information into call_data, you are free to add or alter its contents as you wish.
responders.submitters.SubmitData.fail_id: fail_ident: If you raise a FailPage exception in your submit_data function then the fail_ident page will be called.
responders.submitters.SubmitData.final_p:
After calling your submit_data function, the target page will be called next, which could be another responder.

If it is not a responder, typically a template page, then your end_call function will be called and the target page widget fields will be filled in from the skicall object.

If your submit_data function raises a FailPage exception, then the fail page will be called instead, or if your submit_data raises a GoTo exception, a jump will be made to the page specified by the GoTo.
responders.submitters.SubmitData.submit_:
You should define the function:

submit_data(skicall)

This function will be called by the SubmitData responder with the skicall object as the argument. Typically you would write the function to populate PageData and SectionData objects with widgfields as keys, and values to insert into the fields. These objects are then used to update skicall using skicall.update(pagedata).

This SubmitData responder requires your function to return 'None'.

On returning from this function the call will be passed to the responder's target page, which could typically be a template page (in which case your end_call function will be called next) or it could be another responder. If required a GoTo exception could be raised to jump elsewhere, or a FailPage exception could be raised to jump to the responders failure page with an error message.

When your function submit_data is called, it will have argument skicall which is an object with attributes pertaining to this call.

The SubmitData responder sets the skicall.submit_dict attribute as a dictionary with keys:

'number', the number portion of the  ident (project, number) of this responder.
'target_ident', the target page ident.
'fail_ident', the fail page ident.
'project_brief' with the project brief description.
'responder_brief' with the responder brief description.
'error_dict' which is normally an empty dictionary but will contain widgfields and values which have failed validation tests if this is the 'fail' responder called after a validation failure.
responders.submitters.SubmitData.target_: Target Page: The ident or label of the page this responder will pass the call to, it could be another responder which in turn will pass the call ultimately to a template or JSON page etc.
responders.submitters.SubmitIterator: The submit_data function called by this responder should return a binary iterator. The page_type argument of the end_call function will be SubmitIterator.
responders.submitters.SubmitIterator.cal:
The skicall.call_data attribute is a dictionary, which can be set with any information you require during the course of a call. It's main use being to provide a method of passing data between your start_call, submit_data and end_call functions.

Typically you might include username or authorization status flags in this dictionary, and pass this from your 'start_call' function through to your submit_data function. This status being used to determine what data to return to the client.

This SubmitIterator responder does not set any new information into call_data, you are free to add or alter its contents as you wish.
responders.submitters.SubmitIterator.fin: skicall can be updated with a PageData object which can have attributes set of 'status' and 'headers', or 'mimetype' and 'content_length' if 'headers' is not set.
responders.submitters.SubmitIterator.sub:
You should define the function:

submit_data(skicall)

This function will be called by the SubmitIterator responder with the skicall object as the argument.

This SubmitIterator responder requires your function to return a binary iterator which will be returned to the calling client. The data transmitted is not taken from the skicall object apart from:

PageData().status attribute which will be used if given.
PageData().headers attribute which will be used if given.

PageData().mimetype attribute will be appended to headers as the 'content-type' if PageData().headers is not set.
PageData().content_length attribute - appended to headers if headers is not set.

Otherwise the default headers will be:
[('cache-control','no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate'),
('Pragma', 'no-cache'),
( 'Expires', '0')]

As this generates the file to be returned, no target page is requested, and the end_call function will be called directly after this call to submit_data.

When your function submit_data is called, it will have argument skicall which is an object with attributes pertaining to this call.

The SubmitIterator responder sets the skicall.submit_dict attribute as a dictionary with keys:

'number', the number portion of the  ident (project, number) of this responder.
'fail_ident', the fail page ident.
'project_brief' with the project brief description.
'responder_brief' with the responder brief description.
'error_dict' which is normally an empty dictionary but will contain widgfields and values which have failed validation tests if this is the 'fail' responder called after a validation failure.
responders.submitters.SubmitJSON: This responder is intended to provide JSON data as a service to an external application. Your submit_data should return a dictionary, not widgfields, but any data you like which can be transformed to JSON. The page_type argument of the end_call function will be SubmitJSON.
responders.submitters.SubmitJSON.call_da:
The skicall.call_data attribute is a dictionary, which can be set with any information you require during the course of a call. It's main use being to provide a method of passing data between your start_call, submit_data and end_call functions.

Typically you might include username or authorization status flags in this dictionary, and pass this from your 'start_call' function through to your submit_data function. This status being used to determine what data to return to the client.

This SubmitJSON responder does not set any new information into call_data, you are free to add or alter its contents as you wish.
responders.submitters.SubmitJSON.final_p: Typically used to provide JSON data to an external request that does not expect widgfields. Returns a JSON file with header 'content-type application/json'.
responders.submitters.SubmitJSON.submit_:
You should define the function:

submit_data(skicall)

This function will be called by the SubmitJSON responder with the skicall object as the argument.

This SubmitJSON responder requires your function to return a dictionary containing data which will be returned to the calling client as a JSON file. The data transmitted is not taken from the skicall object apart from PageData().status attribute and PageData().headers attribute which will be used if given.

As this generates the file to be returned, no target page is requested, and the end_call function will be called directly after this call to submit_data.

When your function submit_data is called, it will have argument skicall which is an object with attributes pertaining to this call.

The SubmitJSON responder sets the skicall.submit_dict attribute as a dictionary with keys:

'number', the number portion of the  ident (project, number) of this responder.
'fail_ident', the fail page ident.
'project_brief' with the project brief description.
'responder_brief' with the responder brief description.
'error_dict' which is normally an empty dictionary but will contain widgfields and values which have failed validation tests if this is the 'fail' responder called after a validation failure.
responders.submitters.SubmitPlainText: This responder is intended to provide plain text as a service to an external application. Your submit_data function should return a string which will be set as the returned contents. The page_type argument of the end_call function will be SubmitPlainText.
responders.submitters.SubmitPlainText.ca:
The skicall.call_data attribute is a dictionary, which can be set with any information you require during the course of a call. It's main use being to provide a method of passing data between your start_call, submit_data and end_call functions.

Typically you might include username or authorization status flags in this dictionary, and pass this from your 'start_call' function through to your submit_data function. This status being used to determine what data to return to the client.

This SubmitPlainText responder does not set any new information into call_data, you are free to add or alter its contents as you wish.
responders.submitters.SubmitPlainText.fi: Returns a page of plain text, not HTML, with header 'content-type text/plain'.
responders.submitters.SubmitPlainText.su:
You should define the function:

submit_data(skicall)

This function will be called by the SubmitPlainText responder with the skicall object as the argument.

This SubmitPlainText responder requires your function to return a string which will be returned to the calling client as a text file. The data transmitted is not taken from the skicall object apart from PageData().status attribute and PageData().headers attribute which will be used if given.

As this generates the file to be returned, no target page is requested, and the end_call function will be called directly after this call to submit_data.

When your function submit_data is called, it will have argument skicall which is an object with attributes pertaining to this call.

The SubmitPlainText responder sets the skicall.submit_dict attribute as a dictionary with keys:

'number', the number portion of the  ident (project, number) of this responder.
'fail_ident', the fail page ident.
'project_brief' with the project brief description.
'responder_brief' with the responder brief description.
'error_dict' which is normally an empty dictionary but will contain widgfields and values which have failed validation tests if this is the 'fail' responder called after a validation failure.
responders.widget: Set the section alias and widget name and field this Responder will check. If the widget is not in a section, leave the section alias blank.
skipole.py intro: Skipole is a web framework, allowing you to create web folders, pages and widgets. These interact with three python functions which you provide. You now have the option of opening a pre-existing project, or creating a new one.
